physicalDescription: Vellum, about 9 7/8 in. by 6 1/2, consisting of 187 leaves, many of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1 , 12 , 18 , 98 , 121 , 123 , 184 , 186 , and 187 . The quires, signed with letters, are 23 in number. Leaves are wanting after foll. 9 , 92 , 93 , 95 , 96 , 122 , 131 , 137 , 141 , 145 , 151 , 153 , 154 , 155 , 161 , 164 , 165 , 166 , 169 , 171 , 173 and 186 . Each page is divided into two columns, of from 30 to 36 lines.

Paper, about 6 7/8 in. by 5 1/8, consisting of 140 leaves, some of which are much stained, and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî4, 53, 54, 121, and 136‚Äî140. The quires, signed with letters, were 15 or 16 in number. Leaves are wanting at the beginning, as well as after foll. 4, 12 (one), 52 (one), and 136. There are from 18 to 25 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 10 in. by 6 1/2, consisting of 73 leaves, a few of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 1 and 56 . The quires, signed with arithmetical figures, are ten in number, the last being imperfect, owing to the loss of two leaves after fol. 72 . There are from 29 to 44 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 7 3/8 in. by 5 1/4, consisting of 32 leaves, the first of which is slightly torn. The quires, four in number (the last imperfect), are signed with letters. Each page has from 26 to 30 lines. This manuscript is written in a neat, regular hand of about the xth cent.,

Paper, about 10 in. by 6 3/4, consisting of 90 leaves, some of which are much torn, especially foll. 46, 55, 56, 60‚Äî62, 68, 69, and 90. The quires, 13 in number, are signed with letters, from ‹ê to ‹ò and from ‹ó to ‹ù‹ê. Leaves are wanting after foll. 55, 61, 67, and 89. There are from 21 to 28 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 8 1/4 in. by 5 1/8, consisting of 123 leaves, many of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî5 , 18 , 19 , 22 , 24‚Äî26 , 31 , 35 , 41‚Äî46 , 52 , 77 , 78 , 81 , 93 , 106 , 107 , and 115 . The quires must originally have been at least 17 in number, but the seventh and the last are lost, and there is also a lacuna after fol. 68 . They are signed with letters, from ‹ê to ‹• . The number of lines in each page varies from 18 to 28.
A vellum leaf, 8 5/8 in. by 5 1/2, much stained and torn.
Thirteen vellum leaves, about 11 in. by 8, several of which are much stained and torn, and two are mere fragments. From 32 to 41 lines.

Eleven vellum leaves, about 10 3/8 in. by 7 1/2, nearly all more or less stained and mutilated. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 37 to 40 lines. These leaves belong to the service-book Add. 14,509 .
Two vellum leaves, much soiled and torn, about 10 1/4 in. by 7 7/8.
Four vellum leaves, about 10 7/8 in. by 7 1/8, the first and last of which are much torn. There are 29 or 30 lines in each page.
Two vellum leaves, 9 1/2 in. by 6 7/8.
Nine vellum leaves, about 9 5/8 in. by 6 3/4, most of which are much stained and soiled. There are from 18 to 21 lines in each page.
A vellum leaf, much stained and torn, evidently the last of a volume.
A vellum leaf, 10 7/8 in. by 7 1/8, much soiled.
A vellum leaf, much mutilated.
A vellum leaf, about 10 1/4 in. by 7, much soiled and torn, evidently one of the flyleaves of a manuscript.
A vellum leaf, about 10 1/4 in. by 7 5/8, much torn.
A vellum leaf, about 10 ¬º in. by 7.
A vellum leaf, 11 in. by 7 ¬º.
A vellum leaf, about 9 7/8 in. by 6 5/8 much torn.
The upper half of a vellum leaf.
Two vellum leaves, l0 ¬æ in. by 6 7/8, apparently fly-leaves of the same manuscript.

Vellum, about 8 3/4 in. by 5 1/4, consisting of 83 leaves, some of which are much stained and others slightly torn, especially foll. 63 and 83. The quires are at present signed with letters, from ‹ê to ‹õ, but what the original signatures were, can no longer be discerned. There are from 19 to 24 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 9 3/4 in. by 6 1/2, consisting of 108 leaves. The quires, eleven in number, are signed with both letters and arithmetical figures, thus: etc. There are from 20 to 22 lines in each page. The character is an elegant, regular Es·π≠rangƒïlƒÅ, of the earlier half of the viiithcent. Vowels have been added in a few cases by a later hand (e.g. foll. 15 band 16 a, ‹ª‹∞‹Ω, ‹ª‹Ω, ‹ª‹∫‹Ω, ‹ª‹≥‹Ω, , ).

Vellum, about 9 7/8 in. by 6 5/8, consisting of 61 leaves (Add. 12,133, foll. 109‚Äî169), some of which are slightly stained and the last is much torn. The quires, signed with letters, were originally eight in number, but the signatures now run from ‹ù‹íto ‹ù‹ö. Leaves are wanting at the beginning, and after foll. 112, 113, 119, 120, and 128. There are 25 or 26 lines in each page. The writing is a fine, regular Estrangela of the viiith cent.

Vellum, about 10 1/4 in. by 6 7/8, consisting of 85 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 6, 8, 9, 22, 32, 40, 41, 43, and 48. The quires were originally 15 in number, but ‹ò , ‹õ and ‹ù‹ê are lost, and several others are very imperfect. They are signed with Syriac letters, and also with either Greek letters or Syriac arithmetical figures; e.g. fol. 20 b, ÔøΩ; fol. 41 b,ÔøΩ; fol. 44 a, ÔøΩ; fol. 57 a, ÔøΩ; fol. 67 a, ÔøΩ; fol. 77 a, ÔøΩ. Leaves are wanting after foll. 8, 9, 10, 21, 31, 42, 43, 44, 45, 46, 47, and 56. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 39 to 44 lines. The original description of this manuscript by William Wright includes characters, symbols, or illustrations which cannot be represented. Please consult the attached image.

Vellum, about 7 1/4 in. by 5 1/2, consisting of 140 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî8, 70, 71, 76, 77, 79, and 140. Leaves are wanting after foll. 8, 78, and 86. The quires, signed with letters, are 15 in number. There are from 20 to 24 lines in each page. This volume is written in a good, regular EstrangƒõlƒÅ, and dated A.Gr. 964, A.D. 653.

Eighteen vellum leaves, about 10 3/4 in. by 8 3/8, nearly all more or less stained, torn, and mutilated. The quires are signed with letters (fol. 6 b, ‹õ). Each page is divided into two columns, of from 34 to 37 lines. The writing is a small, elegant, Edessene EstrangƒõlƒÅ, of the vth or vith cent.
Vellum leaf. This folio has been used in binding a volume of the discourses of Jacob of Batnae and is now part of Add. 14,669, foll. 1-18 .
A vellum leaf, much mutilated. The writing is neat and regular, in double columns, in a hand of the xth cent.
Two vellum leaves, about 11 1/2 in. by 8 1/4, unfortunately much soiled and torn; written in double columns of 34 or 35 lines, in a fine Edessene hand of the vith cent.
A vellum leaf, about 10 1/2 in. by 6 5/8, much torn, written in a good, regular hand of the xth cent.
Two vellum leaves, about 10 in. by 7 1/2, both slightly stained and torn, written in double columns of 25 or 26 lines. The writing is a fine, large Estrangela of the vith cent.
A vellum leaf, about 10 in. by 7 1/2, much torn, written in double columns of 27 or 28 lines, in a good, regular Estrangela of the viith cent.
A vellum leaf, 10 ¬æ in. by 8 ¬º , slightly torn. It is written in double columns, in an inelegant Estrangela of about the xiith cent.
Two vellum leaves, about 9 7/8 in. by 7 1/2, both much soiled. They are written in double columns of from 25 to 27 lines, in a good, regular Estrangela of the viith cent.

Five vellum leaves, about 11 1/4 in. by 8 1/2, all more or less stained and torn (Add. 14,669, foll. 29‚Äî33). They are written in double columns of 26 or 27 lines, in a large, regular Estrangela of the vith or viith cent.

Three vellum leaves, about 11 1/2 in. by 8 3/8, much stained and torn, written in double columns of from 21 to 23 lines (Add. 14,669, foll. 34‚Äî36). The writing is a large, elegant Estrangela of the vith cent.
A vellum leaf, about 9 7/8 in. by 7, much stained and torn, written in double, columns of 22 or 23 lines. The character is a large, regular Estrangela of the vith cent.

Nineteen vellum leaves, about 11 in. by 8, most of which are more or less stained and torn (Add. 14,669, foll. 38‚Äî56). The quires were signed with letters (fol. 51 a, ‹ò). There are from 35 to 41 lines in each page. The writing is a good, regular, Nestorian Estrangela, with occasional Syriac vowels and other marks, of about the ixth cent.
Three vellum leaves, about 10 1/2 in. by 8 3/4, slightly stained and torn, written in double columns of from 24 to 26 lines, in a good, regular Estrangela of the vith or viith cent.

Vellum, about 7 1/4 in. by 4 5/8, consisting of 64 leaves, many of which are stained by water, and a few slightly torn, especially foll. 1, 55, and 64. The quires, eight in number, are signed with letters. Each page has from 19 to 21 lines. This volume is written in a neat, regular Estrangelaof the vithcent,., certainly previous to the year 894, A.D. 583,

Vellum, 9 ¬Ω in. by 6 3/8 , consisting of 11 leaves, the last of which is much torn and the first slightly so. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 28 to 30 lines. This manuscript is written in a good, regular hand of about the xth cent.

Vellum, about 93/8in. by 61/8, consisting of 13 leaves (Add. 12,172, foll. 12‚Äî24), all more or less stained and soiled. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 27 to34 lines. This manuscript is written in a good, regular hand of about the xth cent.

Vellum, about 93/8in. by 61/8, consisting of 30 leaves (Add. 12,172, foll. 25‚Äî54), some of which are much stained and soiled. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 27 to 31 lines.The character is a good, regular cursive of about the xth cent.
Vellum, about 9 3/8 in. by 6 1/8. These leaves are palimpsest and now part of Add. 12,172, foll. 25-54 .

Vellum, about 9 1/2 in. by 6 1/8, consisting of ten leaves (Add. 12,172, foll. 55‚Äî64), thefirst and last of which are much torn. Each page has from 26 to 30 lines. The writing is partly Estrangela, partly cursive, of the ixth cent.

Vellum, about 9 1/4 in. by 6 3/8, consisting of 27 leaves, a few of which are much soiled and torn, especially foll. 1, 2, 6 and 9. The quires are signed with letters, but only ‹ù‹í(fol. 18 a) is complete. At present leaves are wanting at the beginning and end, as well asafter foll. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 9 and 17. There are from 25 to 29 lines in each page. This volume is written in a neat, regular hand of the ixth cent.
Vellum, about 9 1/2 in. by 6 3/8, consisting of 71 leaves ( Add. 12,172, foll. 65‚Äî135 ), a few of which are much soiled and slightly torn. The quires, eight in number, are signed with letters.

Vellum, about 9 1/2 in. by 6 3/8, consisting of 61 leaves (See Add. 12,172, foll. 165-196 ). The quires, six in number, are signed with letters. There are from 22 to 33 lines in each page. It is made up of parts of two manuscripts, the one (Add. 12,172, foll. 136-164 ) of the ixth or xth cent. , the other (Add. 12,172, foll. 165-196 ) of the xth or xith cent.

Vellum, about 9 1/2 in. by 6 3/8, consisting of 61 leaves (See Add. 12,172, foll. 136-164 ). The quires, six in number, are signed with letters. There are from 22 to 33 lines in each page. It is made up of parts of two manuscripts, the one (Add. 12,172, foll. 136-164 ) of the ixth or xth cent. , the other (Add. 12,172, foll. 165-196 ) of the xth or xith cent.

Vellum, about 8 3/8 in. by 5 7/8, consisting of 38 leaves (Add. 12,172, foll. 197‚Äî234). The quires seem to have been signed with both letters and arithmetical figures (see fol. 204); but several of them are either wanting or very defective. Each page has from 19 to 22 lines. This manuscript is beautifully written, in a large, regular Estrangelaof the vithor viithcent. A few vowel-points have been added by a later hand.

Paper, about 10 1/4 in. by 6 7/8, consisting of 220 leaves. The quires, signed with letters, are 28 in number. A single leaf is wanting after fol. 185. There are from 18 to 22 lines in each page. This volume is written in a rather inelegant, Malkite hand, and dated A. Gr. 1533 , A.D. 1222 .
Eight paper leaves, about 10 1/2 in. by 6 3/4, of which the first two and the last are much torn. There are from 34 to 36 lines in each page.

physicalDescription: Four leaves from a paper manuscript (Add. 17,267, foll. 9‚Äî12), about 10 1/2 in. by 6 3/4, with from 32 to 36 lines in each page.

materialTextNode: Ten leaves from a paper manuscript
physicalDescription: Ten leaves from a paper manuscript (Add. 17,267, foll. 13‚Äî22), about 10 1/2 in. by 6 3/4, with from 38 to 41 lines in each page.

materialTextNode: Eleven leaves from a paper manuscript
physicalDescription: Eleven leaves from a paper manuscript (Add. 17,267, foll. 23‚Äî33), about 10 1/2 in. by 6 3/4, with from 28 to 31 lines in each page.
Paper, about 10 1/2 in. by 6 3/4, consisting of 16 leaves (Add. 17,267, foll. 34‚Äî49), the last of which is much mutilated. There are from 28 to as many as 54 lines in each page.
Paper, about 10 1/2 in. by 6 3/4, consisting of 26 leaves (Add. 17,267, foll. 50‚Äî75), some of which are much torn, especially foll. 50‚Äî53, 55, and 56. There are from 25 to 35 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 9 1/8 in. by 7, consisting of 28 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî5, 9, 12 and 23. The quires are now only 4 in number, of which the 3d and 4th are very imperfect, leaves being wanting after foll. 22, 26 and 28. What the original signatures were, is not apparent; later hands have marked the quires with letters, and with arithmetical figures, and one reader has numbered the pages with Coptic ciphers (on the verse at the top). Each page is divided into two columns, of from 28 to 33 lines.

Vellum, about 11 1/2 in. by 7 3/8, consisting of 268 leaves, some of which, especially near the beginning and end, are much stained and torn. The quires, 27 in number, are signed with letters. With the exception of foll. 1 and 267, each page is divided into two columns, of from 43 to 61 lines.

Vellum, about 12 ¬æ in. by 9 1/8, consisting of 60 leaves, several of which are much stained and soiled, especially foll. 5 and 8. The quires, signed with letters, were originally 14 in number, but the first 8 are either lost or very imperfect, leaves being wanting at the beginning, as well as after foll. 1, 3, 4, 6 and 7. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 33 to 38 lines.

Vellum, about 10 3/4 in. by 7 3/8 leaves, one of which (fol. 29) is much stained and torn. The quires are signed with letters. From fol. 91 b to the end, the pages are divided into two columns. There are from 30 to 35 lines in each full page or column. The writing of the text is a fine regular EstrangƒõlƒÅ, but the notes are in a smaller, cursive character. Leaves are wanting after foll. 31, 32, and 33. This volume is dated A. Gr. 1115, A.D. 804

Paper, about 10 5/8 in. by 7 5/8, consisting of 230 leaves, a few of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 92, 101, and 228‚Äî230. The quires are signed with letters from ‹ô to ‹†‹í , but their original number is uncertain, there being lacunae after foll. 21, 131, 151, 161, 181, 187, 197, 217, and 225. The first six quires have been wholly lost, and of the seventh only the last leaf remains. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 23 to 33 lines.

Vellum, about 10 1/4 in. by 7 1/8, consisting of 311 leaves, some of which are much stained, defaced, and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî18, 23, 26, 35, 36, 44, 45, and 308‚Äî311. The quires, signed with letters, are 30 in number. Leaves are wanting after foll. 11, 14, 16, 18, 35,108,113 and 300. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 27 to 40 lines. This volume is written in a good, current hand, dated A. Gr. 1204 , A.D. 893

Vellum, about 8 ¬º in. by 5 1/8 , consisting of 212 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn. The quires, apparently 22 in number, have no signatures. There are from 22 to 30 lines in each page. This volume is palimpsest (with the exception of foll. 109‚Äî112).
The first of two older manuscripts which comprise the lower text of this palimpsest manuscript.

The second of two older manuscripts which comprise the lower text of this palimpsest manuscript. Supplemental leaves have been added to this older manuscript in the ixth or xth cent.; for example, foll. 27, 36, 37, 46, 49, 54, 65, 74, 75, 84, and 207‚Äî211.
Vellum, 8 3/4 in. by 5 3/8, consisting of 18 leaves, written in a good, regular hand of the viith cent., with from 23 to 25 lines in each page. There is a considerable lacuna after fol. 10.
Five vellum leaves, about 8 5/8 in. by 5 3/8, all more or less stained and the last much mutilated (Add. 17,160, foll. 19‚Äî23). Each page is divided into two columns of 29 or 30 lines.
Three vellum leaves, about 8 5/8 in. by 5 1/4, the second and third of which are much torn (Add. 17,160, foll. 24‚Äî26). Each page is divided into two columns, of from 28 to 36 lines.
A vellum leaf, much stained and mutilated. The page is divided into two columns, of from 37 to 39 lines.
A vellum leaf, 8 1/2 in., by 5 1/4, slightly stained and torn. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 31 to 33 lines.
Two vellum leaves, about 8 1/8 in. by 5 1/4, slightly soiled and mutilated (Add. 17,160, foll. 29, 30). Each page is divided into two columns, of from 26 to 34 lines.

Paper, about 5 ¬Ω in. by 3 ¬Ω, consisting, according to the present numeration, of 101, but in reality of only 75 leaves, most of which are much stained by water and torn, more especially foll. 1‚Äî11, and 80‚Äî101. The volume is very defective, both at the beginning and end, and a leaf is wanting after fol. 59. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 16 to 20 lines. The difference is owing to the insertion of slips of paper, on which such portions of the text as had become illegible were copied out by a later hand. These slips were originally pasted down upon the leaves, but have now become loosened, and are numbered as separate folios.

Vellum, about 8 7/8 in. by 5 7/8, consisting of 92 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and soiled. The quires, signed with letters, are 9 in number; and there are from 30 to 42 lines in each page.

Vellum about 7 7/8 in. by 6, consisting of 27 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 11, 12, and 15‚Äî17. The quires are signed with letters, but only two of them are complete, ‹õ and ‹ù‹ô. A later hand has marked them with Greek letters, Œò and ŒôŒñ. Leaves are wanting at the beginning and end, as well as after foll. 10, 11, 12, 14, 15, and 25. There are from 19 to 23 lines in each page. This manuscript is written in a good, regular hand of the xth cent.
A vellum leaf, much stained and torn, written in a good, regular Estrangela of the viith cent.

Vellum, about 8 3/8 in. by 6 1/8, consisting of 13 leaves (Add. 14,630, foll. 29‚Äî41), all slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 29‚Äî32, 38, and 41. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 33 to 38 lines. This manuscript is written in a neat hand of the ixth cent.

Vellum, about 8 3/8 in. by 5 3/8, consisting of 30 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 2, 14, 15, 23‚Äî26, and 28. The quires are signed with arithmetical figures (fol. 15 a, %). Leaves are wanting at the beginning, and after foll. 1, 7, 22, 26, 27, and 28. There are from 20 to 25 lines in each page.
Vellum leaves, about 9 ¬º in. by 5 ¬æ, some of which are much stained and slightly torn, especially at the beginning. There are from 24 to 29 lines in each page.

Vellum leaves, about 9 ¬º in. by 5 ¬æ, some of which are much stained and slightly torn, especially at the beginning and end. The quires, signed with letters, are 19 in number. There are from 24 to 29 lines in each page.
Vellum leaf, about 9 ¬º in. by 5 ¬æ. There are from 24 to 29 lines in each page.
Vellum leaves, about 9 ¬º in. by 5 ¬æ, some of which are much stained and slightly torn, especially at the end. There are from 24 to 29 lines in each page.

Paper, about 12 3/4 in. by 8 5/8, consisting of 222 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 31, 59, 68, 96, 107, 118, 221, and 222. The quires, signed with letters, were originally 24 in number, but the first two have been lost. A single leaf is wanting after fol. 31, and another after fol. 168; and nearly the whole of fol. 145 has been torn out. Each page is divided into two columns of 25 lines.
Two paper leaves, about 10 1/2 in. by 6 7/8, the second of which is much torn. The writing is a neat, regular cursive of the xiiith or xivth cent.
A paper leaf, 10 3/4 in. by 6 7/8, slightly mutilated. It is written in a good hand of about the xiiith cent.
Six paper leaves, about 10 1/8 in. by 6 ¬æ. The writing is good and regular, of the xiiith cent., with from 18 to 20 lines in each page.
Two paper leaves, about 6 7/8 in. by 5, both much stained and torn, with 12 or 13 lines in each page. The writing is large and inelegant, of the xiith or xiiith cent.
A paper leaf, 9 7/8 in. by 6 7/8, written in an inelegant hand of about the xivth cent.

Nine paper leaves, about 9 3/4 in. by 6 3/4, several of which are much torn (Add. 14,736, foll. 13‚Äî21). The quires are signed with Syriac and Armenian letters (foll. 18 b, 19 a). There are from 15 to 17 lines in each page. The writing is large and coarse, of the xiiith cent.

Eleven paper leaves, about 9 7/8 in. by 6 3/4, all more or less stained and torn (Add. 14,736, foll. 22‚Äî32). There are from 33 to 36 lines in each page. The writing is good and regular, of the xiiith cent.
A paper leaf, much torn, written in an inelegant hand of the xiiith cent.
A paper leaf, 10 1/8 in. by 6 1/2, the first of the sixth quire of a manuscript. It contains part of an Anaphora, written in a good hand of the xiiith cent., with 17 lines on each page.
Thirteen paper leaves, 10 in. by 6 7/8. The writing is inelegant, of the xiith or xiiith cent. There are from 23 to 25 lines in each page.
A paper leaf, much mutilated, written in a good, regular hand of the xiiith cent.

Four paper leaves, about 9 3/4 in. by 6 5/8, the first of which is slightly torn (Add. 14,736, foll. 49‚Äî52). They are numbered with Coptic arithmetical figures from 272 ( êã¥êã∞êã¢ ) to 275 ( êã¥êã∞êã• ); and the last three formed the 23rd quire of a manuscript. There are 21 lines in each page. They are dated A. Gr. 1794 , A.D. 1483 .
Three paper leaves, slightly torn, about 9 ¬º in. by 6, written in a fair hand of the xiiith cent., with 20 or 21 lines in each page.
Two paper leaves, about 10 5/8 in. by 6 7/8, with 22 lines in each page.
A paper leaf, about 10 1/2, by 6 7/8, slightly stained and torn, written in a good hand of the xvth cent.
A paper leaf, 10 5/8 in. by 6 7/8, written in a good, regular hand of the xvth cent.
A paper leaf, about 10 in. by 6 1/2, much mutilated. Written in a good hand of the xvth cent.
Three paper leaves, about 10 3/4 in. by 7, much stained and torn. The writing, which is, for the most part, in two columns of from 21 to 33 lines, is neat and regular, of the xvth cent.
Two paper leaves, about 10 3/4 in. by 6 7/8, the second of which is much torn (Add. 14,736, foll. 64 and 65). They are neatly written, dated A. Gr. 1803, A.D. 1492.
A paper leaf, much torn, apparently of the xvith cent.

Vellum, about 8 7/8 in. by 6 1/8, consisting of 228 leaves, many of which are more or less stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî32, 37, 38, 41, 216, 220, 221, and 224‚Äî228. The quires, originally 25 in number, are signed with both letters and arithmetical figures (e. g. fol. 102, ‹ù‹ì; fol. 170, ‹ü; etc.). The later signatures are erroneous. Leaves are wanting at the beginning, and after foll. 4 and 12. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 29 to 35 lines. This volume is written in a good, regular EstrangƒõlƒÅ of the viith cent.

Vellum, about 9 7/8 in. by 6 5/8, consisting of 52 leaves, some of which are slightly stained, especially at the beginning. The quires, signed with letters, are 6 in number. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 31 to 42 lines.

Vellum, about 11 in. by 7 1/2, consisting of 219 leaves, a few of which, especially near the beginning and end, are slightly stained and torn. The quires, signed with letters, were originally 23 in number, but the whole of the first is now lost, as well as the last leaf of the second. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 37 to 49 lines.

volume about 7 in. by 6 1/8, consisting of 179 leaves. Of these foll. 1‚Äî24 and 104‚Äî179 are vellum, but the rest are a coarse, brownish paper. Many of the latter are much stained and torn, especially foll. 29 , 30 , 34‚Äî37 , 59 , 60 , 64 , and 68‚Äî103 . The quires, signed with letters, are 16 in number, mostly of 12 leaves. One leaf is missing after fol. 24 , and another after fol. 179 . The number of lines in each page varies from 20 to 28.

Paper, about 6 5/8 in. by 5, consisting of 126 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî3, 13, 30, 118, 124 and 125. The quires, signed with letters, seem to have been 16 in number. Leaves are wanting at the beginning, as well as after foll. 1, 4, 23, 30, 40, 46, 123, and 125. There are from 16 to 19 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 9 7/8 in. by 6 1/2, consisting of 24 leaves, of which two (foll. 1 and 8) are much torn. The original signatures of the quires do not appear. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 33 to 42 lines.
Seven vellum leaves, about 9 3/4i n. by 6 1/4, all of which are much stained by water, and the last two much torn. The number of lines in each page varies from 33 to 37.

Vellum, about 7 5/8 in. by 5 1/4, consisting of 127 leaves, many of which are much stained and soiled, especially near the beginning and end. The quires, 13 in number, are signed with both letters and arithmetical figures (see foll. 29 a, 59 a, 99 a, 109 a, and 119 a), but have been twice renumbered, in part incorrectly, by later hands. Each page has from 21 to 25 lines. The writing is a fine, regular Estrangela of the vith or viith cent.

Vellum, about 9 7/8 in. by 7 7/8, consisting of 128 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 2, 7, 121, 127, and 128. The quires are now signed with letters up to ‹ù‹ò , but what the original signatures were does not appear; they seem to have been also numbered in the reverse way with Greek letters at the top (foll. 31 b, ŒôŒí ; 22 b, ŒôŒì ). Each page is divided into two columns, of from 21 to 26 lines. Fol. 62 is a palimpsest leaf of the ixth or xth cent. , written by the same hand that repaired fol. 121 (which is also partly palimpsest). See Add. MS 14,480 foll. 62, 121, upper text and Add. MS 14,480 foll. 62, 121, lower text

Vellum, about 9 7/8 in. by 7 7/8. Fol. 62 is a palimpsest leaf of the ixth or xth cent. A fragment of the same manuscript has been used to repair fol. 121. See Add. 14,480, foll. 62, 121, lower text .
Vellum, about 9 7/8 in. by 7 7/8. Fol. 62 is palimpsest. A fragment of the same manuscript has been used to repair fol. 121. See Add. 14,480, foll. 62, 121, upper text .

Vellum, about 9 7/8 in. by 8 1/8, consisting of 182 leaves, a few of which are more or less torn, especially foll.89, 104, 173, 178, and 182. The number of quires was 20, but the first is now lost, and the last is imperfect. It does not appear in what way they were originally signed; the more recent signatures (letters) are not always correct. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 22 to 27 lines. The character is a large, regular Estrangelaof the vthor vithcent. Fol. 173 has been repaired with paper, about the xiith cent.

Vellum, about 9 5/8 in. by 7, consisting of 92 leaves, a few of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 2, 10, 82, and 84. The quires, signed with letters, are 9 in number. A leaf is wanting after fol. 82, and nearly the whole of fol. 1 has been torn away. There are from 26 to 33 lines in each page. This volume is palimpsest throughout (see Add. 17,127, lower text ).
Vellum, about 9 5/8 in. by 7. This volume is palimpsest (see Add. 17,127, upper text ).

Vellum, about 9 in. by 5 7/8, consisting of 161 leaves, the first three of which are much stained and torn. The quires were originally 20 in number, but the last two are now lost. They are signed with Syriac letters on the first leaf of each, and by a later hand with Greek letters on the last leaf. The number of lines in each page varies from 26 to 31.
Paper, about 8 3/4 in. by 6 1/4, consisting of 96 leaves. The quires, signed with letters, are ten in number. There are 19 lines in each page.
Paper, about 7 1/2 in. by 5 7/8, consisting of 114 leaves. The quires, signed with letters, are 9 in number. A single leaf is wanting after fol. 113. There are from 21 to 30 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 7 7/8 in. by 5 1/4, consisting of 17 leaves, the first and last of which are slightly stained and torn. The writing on the lower half of fol. 14 b has been inten¬¨tionally erased. The quires are without signatures. There are from 22 to 28 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 8 5/8 in. by 5 5/8, consisting of 108 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî3, 23, 103, and 108. The quires, 11 in number, are signed with letters. Each page has from 30 to 38 lines, only the last four being divided into columns. This manuscript is dated A.D. 615,

Vellum, about 12 3/8 in. by9 ¬º consisting of 135 leaves. The quires, signed with letters, are seventeen in number. Three vellum leaves, about 12 1/4 in. by 9, the second of which is much stained and torn. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 50 to 60 lines. They are written in a small, neat #Estrangela of the viiith cent, or the beginning of the ixth

Seventeen paper leaves, about 14 5/8 in. by 10 5/8, nearly all more or less stained and torn. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 22 to 25 lines. The writing is good and regular, of the xiiith cent.
A paper leaf, 13 in. by 9 ¬Ω, much torn. The pages are divided into two columns of 28 lines. The writing is good and regular, of the xiiith cent.

Three paper leaves, about 10 5/8 in. by 7 1/8, all more or less stained and torn (Add. 17,224, foll. 19‚Äî21). Each page is divided into two columns, of from 25 to 31 lines. The writing is good and regular, of the xiiith or xivth cent., with occasional Greek vowels.

Twelve paper leaves, about 12 7/8 in. by 9 7/8, several of which are stained and torn (Add. 17,224, foll. 22‚Äî33). Each page is divided into two columns, of from 21 to 25 lines. The writing is good and regular, of the xiiith cent., with occasional Greek vowels and other points.

Two paper leaves, about 12 in. by 9 3/4, both much stained and torn (Add. 17,224, foll. 34, 35). Each page is divided into two columns, of 19 or 20 lines. The writing is a large Estrangela of the xiith or xiiith cent., with numerous Syriac vowels and other points.
A paper leaf, much mutilated, of the xiiith cent., apparently one of the fly-leaves of a copy of the Gospels.
Six paper leaves, about 11 ¬æ in. by 10, the first two of which are much torn. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 20 to 23 lines. The writing is good and regular, of the xiiith cent.

Fifteen paper leaves, about 9 7/8 in. by 8, most of which are more or less torn (Add. 17,224, foll. 43‚Äî57). Each page is divided into two columns, of from 14 to 18 lines. The writing is a large, bold Estrangela. They are dated A. Gr. 1484, A.D. 1173

Eight paper leaves, about 10 5/8 in. by 7 5/8, all more or less torn (Add 17,224, foll. 58‚Äî 65). Each page is divided into two columns, of from 17 to 26 lines. The writing is good and regular, of the xiiith cent.
A paper leaf, 10 in. by 6 ¬æ, slightly torn.

Four paper leaves, 10 7/8 in. by 8 1/8, the first of which is slightly torn. Each page is divided info two columns of from 24 to 26 lines. The writing, which is good and regular, is of the xiiith cent.

Part of an illuminated Vellum leaf. It seems to be of the xii cent.
Part of a paper leaf, written in a current hand of the xith or xiith cent.
A paper leaf, about 9 ¬æ in. by 6 5/8, written in a good hand of the xiiith cent.

Vellum, about 8 ¬æ in. by 6, consisting of 164 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 129 and 161. The quires, 17 in number, are signed with letters. There are from 24 to 28 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 10 7/8 in. by 7 7/8, consisting of 69 leaves, several of which are slightly soiled, the first being also torn. The quires, signed with letters, are now 7 in number. There are from 26 to 33 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 10 3/4 in. by 6 3/8, consisting of 189 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll.1, 2, and 184‚Äî189. The quires, 19 in number, are signed with letters. There are from 30 to 46 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 6 5/8 in. by 5, consisting of 90 leaves, the first eight of which, in particular, are slightly stained and mutilated. At present it consists of 12 quires, signed with Syriac (and, at a later period, with Greek) letters, of which the first three and the last are very imperfect. Leaves are wanting at the beginning and end, as well as after foll. 4, 6, 8, and 89. There are from 24 to 29 lines in each page.
A vellum leaf, 7 1/4 in. by 4 7/8.
A vellum leaf, much torn, written in a regular Estrangela of the viiith cent.
A vellum leaf, torn and soiled, written in a small, regular Estrangela of the vith or viith cent. Syriac vowels and diacritical points have been added by a later hand.
Two vellum leaves, about 6 1/2 in. by 4 7/8, much torn and soiled, written in a small, neat hand of the ixth cent. Some part of each rubric is written with bright green paint.
Four vellum leaves, about 7 7/8 in. by 5 1/2, much stained. The writing is good and regular, of the ixth cent., with 24 or 25 lines in each page.
Three vellum leaves, about 6 7/8 in. by 5, much soiled and torn. The writing is neat and regular, of the ixth or xth cent., with 25 or 26 lines in each page.

Twenty vellum leaves, about 6 1/8 in. by 4 7/8, several of which are much stained and torn. The quires are signed with letters. There are from 12 to 17 lines in each page. The writing is of about the xiith cent.
Four vellum leaves, all much soiled and torn. There are 17 or 18 lines in each page. The writing is partly cursive, partly Estrangela, of the xiith or xiiith cent.

A single vellum leaf, 8 5/8 in. by 5 1/4, slightly torn. There are 19 lines in each page. The writing is an elegant EstrangƒõlƒÅ of the vith or viith cent. Some Greek vowels have been added by a later hand.

Nine vellum leaves, about 9 1/8 in. by 5 7/8, of which the first is much mutilated (Add. 14,666, foll. 38‚Äî46). There are 19 or 20 lines in each page. The writing is an elegant Estrangela of the vith or viith cent.
A vellum leaf, about 8 3/4 in. by 5 3/4, slightly torn.
A vellum leaf, about 8 3/4 in. by 5 3/4, much stained and torn, written in a Nestorian hand of the xth cent., with occasional Syriac vowels.
Two vellum leaves, about 7 1/8 in. by 4 7/8, much stained and torn. The writing is good and regular, of the xth or xith cent.
Five vellum leaves, about 8 7/8 in. by 6, slightly soiled and torn (Add. 14,666, foll. 51‚Äî55). The writing is a fine, regular Estrangela of the viith or viiith cent.
This folio has been used as a flyleaf for a volume of discourses of Jacob of Batnae , as appears from the list of contents on the margin.
A vellum leaf, much torn, 7 3/4 in. by 4 7/8. The writing is a small, neat Estrangela. It is the last leaf of a Nestorian manuscript of the New Testament, dated A.Gr. 993, A.H. 63, A.D. 682.
Eight vellum leaves, about 8 7/8 in. by 5 7/8, some of which are slightly stained and torn (Add. 14,666, foll. 57‚Äî64). There are from 24 to 26 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 11 1/4 in. by 7 1/4, consisting of 59 leaves, the first and last of which are blank. Foll. 1‚Äî3 have been almost completely torn out, and fol. 58 is slightly injured. The quires, signed with letters, are 6 in number. A single leaf is wanting after fol. 58 . Each page is divided into two columns, of from 20 to 24 lines.

Vellum, about 8 3/8 in. by 6 1/4, consisting of 140 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî8, 61, 112, 120, 121, 128, and 129. Greek vowels, and the points rukkƒÅkh and kushshƒÅi, have been added on two different occasions, one punctuator having employed red, the other black ink (‹∞, ‹∞, ‹∞, ‹∞, ‹∞, , , , , , , ).

Vellum, about 13 1/4 in. by 8 3/4, consisting of 178 leaves, many of which are stained and soiled. Foll. 140‚Äî159 have been torn and afterwards repaired with paper. The quires, signed with letters, were originally 19 in number, but the sixth is now lost. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 32 to 42 lines.

Vellum, about 12 7/8 in. by 9 3/4, of 211 leaves, a few of which are stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 11, 120, 210, and 211. Vellum, about 8 1/4 in. by 5 1/8, consisting of 89 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn, especially the first and last. The quires, signed with letters, were originally 10 in number, but the first is lost, and a leaf is wanting after fol. 8. The number of lines in each page varies from 19 to 24. This manuscript is palimpsest throughout (see Add. MS 14,500, lower text ).

Vellum, about 8 1/4 in. by 5 1/8, consisting of 89 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn, especially the first and last. The whole of this volume is palimpsest (see Add. MS 14,500, upper text ).

Paper, about 7 1/4, in. by 4 7/8, consisting of 36 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî3 , 14‚Äî17 , and 23‚Äî26 . Paper, about 7 1/2 in. by 5, consisting of 81 leaves (Add. 14,684, foll. 37‚Äî117), some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 110‚Äî112, and 117. Vellum, about 10 1/4 in. by 6 7/8, consisting of 194 leaves, some of which are much stained and slightly torn, especially foll. 4, 5, and 194. The quires, signed with letters, are 21 in number, but the first three are very imperfect, leaves being wanting at the beginning and after foll. 4, 6, 14 and 15. Gr. 880, corresponding to the year 617 of the era of Antioch, or A.D. 569.

Vellum, about 8 1/2 in. by 5 3/8, consisting of 191 leaves. The quires, 21 in number, are signed with letters. Leaves are wanting after foll. 144, 170, and 171. There are from 25 to 30 lines in each page, except in the last quire, where the number varies from 20 to 23. Large portions of this volume are palimpsest (see ( Add. 12,145, lower text ).
Vellum, about 8 1/2 in. by 5 3/8, consisting of 191 leaves. Large portions of this volume are palimpsest, but the older Syriac text is no longer legible (see ( Add. 12,145, upper text ).

Paper, about 19 1/2 in. by 13 5/8, consisting of 227 leaves, many of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 203‚Äî207, 209‚Äî211, and 213‚Äî227. A paper leaf, about 19 1/2 in. by 12 1/2, with the signature ‹ê . The writing is in three columns, of from 41 to 43 lines.

Nine paper leaves, about 19 1/2 in. by 13 3/8 (Add. 11,732, foll. 2299‚Äî237), eight of which formed part of the eighth quire ( ‹ö ) of a large manuscript. Foll. 229, 232, 233, and 236, are much torn; and two leaves are wanting after fol. 232. Each page is divided into two columns of 31 lines.

Vellum, about 9 5/8in. by 6, consisting of 48 leaves. The quires, 5 in number, are now signed with letters. Each page has from 28 to 31 lines. The writing is a fine, regular Estrangela of the viithor viiithcent., except on fol. 3 (originally one of the fly-leaves), which is of the xiith cent

Vellum, about 9 5/8 in. by 6 5/8, consisting of 32 leaves (Add. 12,175, foll. 49‚Äî80), some of which are slightly stained by water. The quires, three in number, are now signed with letters. DCCXXVII.), in which case its date is A.D. 534.

Vellum, about 9 5/8 in. by 6 5/8, consisting of 174 leaves (Add. 12,175, foll. 81‚Äî254). The quires, 17 in number, are signed with letters, originally from ‹ù‹ïto ‹†, but now from ‹ùŸÄto ‹ü‹ò. This manuscript is written in a small, neat hand of the vith cent., the precise date being, apparently, A. Gr. 845, A.D. 534 (see below).

Paper, about 8 5/8 in. by 6 1/8, consisting of 309 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and soiled. The quires, signed with letters, are 31 in number. Vellum, about 9 3/4 in. by 6 1/8, consisting of 90 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1 , 3 , 12 , 42 , and 88‚Äî90 . The quires seem to have been 11 in number, of which the first is lost, and the second imperfect, 8 leaves being missing after fol. 1 . Paper, about 10 in. by 6 3/4, consisting of 490 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 2, 14, 339‚Äî341, 476, and 483‚Äî490. Vellum, about 12 in. by 8 5/8, consisting of 255 leaves, one of which (fol. 10) is much torn. The quires, signed with letters, were originally 27 in number, but the whole of ‹ê is now lost, as well as the first leaf of ‹ì . Each page is divided into two columns, of from 32 to 47 lines.

Vellum, about 7 1/2 in. by 6, consisting of 89 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 1 , 10 , and 11 . The quires, ten in number, are signed with letters. One or two leaves are wanting at the end. There are from 13 to 23 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 16 1/2 in. by 12 1/4, consisting of 84 leaves, many of which are much stained and torn. In all external respects this volume is precisely similar to Add. 12,147 . It must, therefore, have originally contained about 40 quires (fol. 61 is signed ‹†‹ï ); but the greater part of it has been gradually lost and destroyed. Foll. 33 and 34 are supplementary paper leaves, exactly similar to those described in Add. 12,147 . Fol. 63 has also been repaired with paper.

Paper, about 8 7/8 in. by 6 1/4, consisting of 171 leaves. The quires have no signatures. There are from 17 to 23 lines in each page. In the first and larger half of the volume (foll. 3‚Äî104), each page is divided into two columns; in the other, not.

Vellum, about 8 1/4 in. by 6 1/2 , consisting of 207 leaves, many of which arc much stained and a few slightly torn. The quires, 26 in number, are signed with letters, viz. Syriac at the foot of the first page of each quire, and Greek at the top (e.g. foll. 177, Œî , ‹ü‹ì ; 113, ŒôŒí , ‹ù‹ó ; 105, ŒôŒì , ‹ù‹ï ; 97, ŒôŒî , ‹ù‹ì ; 89, ŒôŒï , ‹ù‹í ; 49, Œö , ‹ô ). Paper, about l0 3/8 in. by 6 7/8, consisting of 467 leaves, the first three or four of which are much torn. This manuscript is composed of 40 quires (mostly of 12 leaves), numbered with letters. Each page has from 26 to 36 lines. It is written in the ordinary, cursive character; is dated A. Gr. 1540, A.D. 1229

Vellum, about 10 1/8 in. by 7 ¬º, consisting of 187 leaves, the first two of which are much stained and torn. The quires, signed with letters, are much stained and slightly torn. The quires, signed with letters, are 19 in number, the last having only 3 leaves. Each page has from 23 to 33 lines.

Vellum, about 6 5/8 in. by 4 3/4, consisting of 93 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn, especially the first and last. There are from 17 to 29 lines in each page. This volume is written in a regular, Nestorian hand, of the ixth or xth cent .

Paper, about 10 3/8 in. by 7, consisting of 71 leaves. The quires, signed with letters, are 7 in number. Each page (with the exception of foll. 48 a and 65‚Äî71) is divided into two columns, of from 17 to 21 lines.

Vellum, 9 5/8 in. by 6 3/4, consisting of 81 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and injured along the outer margin. Foll. 1, 3 and 8 of this manuscript are palimpsest, but the lower text on all three has been so carefully erased that scarcely a word is legible.

Vellum, 8 3/8 in. by 5, consisting of 158 leaves, some of which are, slightly stained and torn. Vellum, about 9 7/8 in. by 6 3/4, consisting of 137 leaves, many of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 5, 7, 8, 17, 35, 44, 45, 54, 55, 58‚Äî93 (soaked in oil), 136 and 137. Vellum, about 9 1/2 in. by 6 5/8, consisting of 56 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1 , 2 , 8 , and 56 . Vellum, about 9 in. by 6 1/8, consisting of 93 leaves, many of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 6, 13, 14, 22‚Äî24, 27, 28, 50, 56, 58, 65, 66, 74, 82, 86‚Äî88 and 90‚Äî93. Vellum leaves, about 9 in. by 6 1/8, written in two columns. These leaves are palimpsest (see Add. 14,496, upper text ).
Vellum leaves, about 9 in. by 6 1/8. These leaves are palimpsest (see Add. 14,496, upper text ).
Vellum leaves, about 9 in. by 6 1/8, written in two columns. These leaves are palimpsest (see Add. 14,496, upper text ).

Paper, about 7 in. by 5 1/8, consisting of 258 leaves, a few of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 8‚Äî10, and 252. The quires arc 33 in number. Vellum, about 8 5/8 in. by 6 1/2, consisting of 155 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 4‚Äî6, 39, 137, 138, 141,143, 144, and 153‚Äî155. Vellum, about 10 7/8in. by 8 1/4, consisting of 187 leaves, the first of which is slightly stained and torn. Paper, about 12 3/8 in. by 8 1/4, consisting of 422 leaves. The quires, signed with letters as far as ‹†‹ê , fol. 308 b, are 42 in number. There are from 23 to 35 lines in each page.

Paper, about 8 3/8 in. by 7, consisting of 104 leaves, many of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî28 and 38. The quires, signed with letters, seem to have been 11 in number. Paper, about 8 1/8 in. by 6 5/8, consisting of 23 leaves (Add. 17,242, foll. 105‚Äî127), many of which are much stained and torn. Leaves are wanting at the beginning and end, as well as after foll. 106 , 114 , and 122 . The number of lines in each page varies from 16 to 21.

Vellum, about 8 3/4 in. by 5 1/2, consisting of 129 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 9, 30, 69, 70,128, and 129. Vellum, about 10 3/8 in. by 6 3/4, consisting of 107 leaves, of which a few are slightly stained and torn, especially foil. 8 and 107. The quires, signed with letters, are at present 11 in number. Paper, about 8 1/8 in. by 5 1/2, consisting of 94 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 71 and 79‚Äî94. The quires, signed with letters, are 11 in number. Leaves are wanting after foll. 79, 81, 90, and at the end of the volume. There are from 17 to 24 lines in each page.
Vellum, 11 in. by 8 3/8, consisting of 139 leaves. The quires, signed with letters, are 13 in number. There are from 22 to 32 lines in each page.

Paper, about 6 7/8 in. by 5, consisting of 167 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî9, 101, and 164 ‚Äî167. Vellum, about 10 1/2 in. by 6 5/8, consisting of 201 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and soiled. Paper, about 6 7/8 in. by 5, consisting of 75 leaves, some of which are much soiled and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî7 and 75. The quires, signed with letters, are 7 in number. Leaves are wanting at the beginning, and after foll. 1, 4, 5, and 71. Each page has from 16 to 26 lines.

Paper, about 6 3/4 in. by 5 1/8, consisting of 62 leaves (Add. 14,728, foll. 76‚Äî137), the last two of which are much torn. The quires, signed with letters, are six in number. There are from 17 to 26 lines in each page.
Paper, about 6 5/8 in. by 5, consisting of 70 leaves ( Add. 14,728, foll. 138‚Äî207 ). The quires, signed with letters, are 7 in number. There are from 15 to 20 lines in each page.

Paper, about 6 1/2 in. by 5, consisting of 31 leaves (Add. 14,728, foll. 208‚Äî238), many of which are slightly stained and torn. The quires, signed with letters, are three in number. There are from 20 to 30 lines in each page.

Paper, about 6 1/2 in. by 5, consisting of 30 leaves (Add. 14,728, foll. 239‚Äî268), some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 266‚Äî268. The quires, now three in number, are signed with letters, from ‹ï to ‹ò . There are from 18 to 28 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 12 3/8 in. by 9 3/4, consisting of 43 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî7, 16, 17, and 28. Vellum, about 8 7/8 in. by 5 1/2, consisting of 106 leaves, some of which arc slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 8, 73‚Äî75, 105, and 106. Vellum, about 9 5/8 in. by 6 1/2, consisting of 138 leaves, some of which are much stained, defaced, and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî3, 15, 18, 21, 137 and l38. Paper, about 6 7/8 in. by 5, consisting of 78 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 52, 60, and 73‚Äî78. Paper, about 7 in. by 5 1/8, consisting of 48 leaves (Add. 14,674, foll. 79‚Äî126). It is imperfect both at the beginning and end, and a leaf is wanting after fol. 118. Vellum, about 6 7/8 in. by 4 1/4, consisting of 91 leaves, some of which are, much stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 12, 20, 21, 23, 26, 27, 34‚Äî36, 44, and 91. Paper, about 10 1/8 in. by 6 3/4, consisting of 53 leaves. The quires, signed with letters, are six in number. There are from 12 to 21 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 8 in. by 4 7/8, consisting of 66 leaves, the first three of which are slightly stained. The quires were 8 in number, but the first is now lost. They seem to have been originally signed with arithmetical figures (though the ciphers on foll. 1a and 12a are more recent), but the present signatures are letters. There are from 27 to 31 lines in each page. This manuscript is written in a beautiful, Edessene Estrangela, apparently of the vthcent.; with the exception of fol. 12, which was probably added by the same person who retouched foll. 1‚Äî3.
Vellum, about 8 in. by 4 7/8. This folio is palimpsest (see Add. 14,459 fol. 12, lower text ), perhaps of the xth cent. and was probably added by the same person who retouched foll. 1-3 .
Vellum, about 8 in. by 4 7/8. This folio is palimpsest, from a manuscript of the vith cent. (see Add. 14,459 fol. 12, upper text ).

Vellum, about 8 in. by 5, consisting of 103 leaves, the last 8 of which are much stained and soiled (Add. 14,459, foll. 67‚Äî169). The quires, 11 in number, seem to have been originally signed with arithmetical figures (though the ciphers on fol. 67 aare more recent), but the present signatures are letters (from ‹õto ‹ù‹õ). Vellum, about 8 in. by 5. This folio is a palimpsest leaf of the ixth or xth cent. (see Add. 14,459 fol. 74, lower text )
Vellum, about 8 in. by 5. This folio is a palimpsest leaf from a manuscript in double columns of the vith cent. (see Add. 14,459 fol. 74, upper text ).

Paper, about 7 in. by 4 7/8, consisting of 69 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî3, 7, 8, 10, 41, and. 42. Vellum leaves, several of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 12 and 17. The quires are signed with letters, and each page is divided into two columns. These leaves are taken from a manuscript of the ixth cent.

Vellum, about 8 in. by 5 1/2, consisting of 18 leaves, a few of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 154. These leaves are palimpsest (see Add. 18817, foll. 137-154 lower text ).

Vellum, about 8 in. by 5 1/2, consisting of 18 leaves, a few of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 154. These leaves are palimpsest (see Add. 18817, foll. 137-154 upper text ). Vellum, about 10 in. by 6 3/4, consisting of 43 leaves. The quires, five in number, are signed with letters. There are from 23 to 27 lines in each page. This manuscript is written in a beautiful, regular Estrangƒõla, dated A. Gr. 1037, A.D. 726

Vellum, about 10 1/4 in. by6 7/8, consisting of 164 leaves (Add. 12,135, foll. 44‚Äî207), some of which are much injured by damp, especially at the beginning and end. Vellum, about 10 in. by 6 ¬æ, consisting of 27 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 2‚Äî5, 11, and 27. The quires are signed with letters (fol. 22 a, ‹ô ). Vellum, about 5 1/4 in. by 3 1/2, consisting of 84 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî7, 46, 52‚Äî54, 64, 81‚Äî84. The quires, signed with letters, are 8 in number. Vellum, about 7 1/8 in, by 4 5/8, consisting of 63 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî3, 12, 17‚Äî19, 45, and 46. Paper, about 10 1/8 in. by 6 7/8, consisting of 51 leaves. The quires, signed with letters, are six in number. There are from 15 to 20 lines in each page. It is the companion volume to Add. 14,702 .

Paper, about 10 1/4 in. by 7, consisting of 70 leaves (Add. 14,708, foll. 52-121), the first two of which are slightly stained and torn. The quires, signed with letters, are 7 in number. A leaf is wanting after fol. 59. There are from 17 to 22 lines in each page.

Paper, about 10 1/4 in. by 7, consisting of 40 leaves (Add. 14,708, foll. 122‚Äî161), some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 122, 125, 126, 135, 156, and 161. Vellum, about 11 3/8 in. by 7 1/4, consisting of 171 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1 , 2 , 5 , 82 , 83 , 90 , 142 , and 171 . Vellum, about 10 1/4 in. by 8 1/8, consisting of 108 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll, 1, 70, 78‚Äî80, and 88. Vellum, 13 7/8 in. by 10 ¬º, consisting of 95 leaves, several of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 69 and 86‚Äî90. Seven vellum leaves, all more or less stained and torn, with from 34 to 37 lines in each page. These leaves are palimpsest. See the lower text of foll. 1, 2, 5-7 ; the lower text of fol. 3 and its more ancient upper text ; and the lower text of fol. 4 .

Foll.1, 2, and 5‚Äî7 are fragments of a Greek manuscript, written in double columns, with 21 lines on each page. Fol. 1 is a very small fragment, on which only a few letters are visible. The the greater part of the outer columns of fol. 2 has been torn away. Fol. 5 is now much torn. Foll. 6 and 7 are small fragments, on which scarcely any of the original writing is legible. These leaves are palimpsest; cf. the upper text .
Across the uncials on fol. 3 there is Greek writing in two columns. It is so faded as to be almost illegible. These leaves are palimpsest; cf. the more recent upper text and the lower text .
Fol. 3 is a leaf from a Greek manuscript, written in double columns, with 28 lines in each page. These leaves are palimpsest; cf. the more recent upper text and the more ancient upper text .
Fol. 4 is a leaf from a Greek manuscript, written in double columns, with 19 lines on each page. These leaves are palimpsest; cf. the upper text .
Two palimpsest leaves, much mutilated; cf. the lower text .
Two palimpsest leaves, much mutilated; cf. the upper text . From a Greek manuscript. A portion of the first leaf is not rewritten.
Eleven vellum leaves, all more or less stained and torn. The leaves of the lower text were folded so as to form a volume measuring about 8 3/4 in. by 5 1/2.

Eleven vellum leaves, all more or less stained and torn, but apparently belonging to the same Coptic manuscript (Add. 14,665, foll. 10‚Äî20). Foll. 17‚Äî19 are the best preserved, and measure about 11 in. by 8 3/4. The text is written in two columns, of from 33 to 39 lines. Foll. 10‚Äî16 are so mutilated, and the ancient writing is so much obliterated, that it is difficult to say, without employing chemical reagents, what portions of Scripture they comprise. Fol. 20 is made up of eight disconnected fragments, merely put together in order to preserve them. This manuscript is palimpsest; cf. the upper text .
Four vellum leaves, about 11 1/4 in. by 8 3/4, much stained and mutilated, and all palimpsest; cf. the lower text .
Four vellum leaves, about 11 1/4 in. by 8 3/4, much stained and mutilated, written in two columns of 26 or 27 lines. All palimpsest; cf. the lower text .

A vellum leaf, much stained and mutilated. It is palimpsest, but rewritten on one side only. The more recent text seems to be part of the same manuscript as the preceding number . The older text, apparently of the xth cent. , is too much effaced to be legible.
Two vellum leaves, about 6 3/8 in. by 5 1/8, slightly stained and soiled. They are palimpsest; cf. the lower text .
Two vellum leaves, about 6 3/8 in. by 5 1/8, slightly stained and soiled. They are palimpsest; cf. the upper text .
The upper half of a vellum leaf, which formed part of the same manuscript as Add. 17,217 , foll. 37 and 38 . It can therefore only be deciphered with difficulty.

Vellum, about 7 1/4 in. by 5 1/8. This volume is palimpsest throughout (see Add. 14,615, upper text ).
Vellum, about 10 1/8 in. by 7 7/8, consisting of 70 leaves. The quires, nine in number, are signed with letters. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 22 to 27 lines.

Paper, about 5 3/4 in. by 3 7/8, consisting of 201 leaves, some of which are much stained and slightly torn, especially foll. 27, 141, 142, 187‚Äî189, and 194‚Äî201. Vellum, about 9 1/4, in. by 6 1/4, consisting of 73 leaves, many of which are more or less stained and a little torn, especially foll. 1, 2, 6, 9, 17, 24, 27, 46, 55, 57, 64‚Äî67, 69, and 70. This volume is written in a fine, clear Estrangela of the vithor viithcent., with the exception of foll. 7, 8, 15, 16, and 71. Of these live leaves, foll. 7, 8, and 16 seem to be of the viiithor ixthcent.; fol. 15 is of the ixthor xthcent.; and fol. 71 is a paper leaf of the xiiithcent. The same person who wrote, fol. 71 has repaired foll. 1, 6, 55, and 67, and retouched several other leaves. In the older portions of the manuscript numerous Greek vowels have been added by several hands (%‹∞, ‹∞, ‹∞, , , , , , , , ,).

Vellum, about 9 in. by 5 1/2, consisting of 146 leaves, many of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî7, 16‚Äî18, 25, and 136‚Äî146. The quires, signed with letters, are 18 in number. There are from 23 to 33 lines in each page.

About the end of the xth cent. , the leaves of the lower text were destroyed by a Syrian monk, who folded them so as to form a volume, at present consisting of 42 leaves, or five quires, signed partly with letters and partly with arithmetical figures, of which the first is now incomplete. Foll. 19 and 20 of the lower text served as fly-leaves to the manuscript in its later form.

Vellum, about l0 3/8 in. by 7 1/4, consisting of 23 leaves, most of which are more or less stained and torn. Foll. 1, 18, 21, and 22, are mutilated, one half of each being lost. These leaves are all that remain of this text. It belongs apparently to the viith or viiith cent. About the end of the xth cent. , these leaves were destroyed by a Syrian monk, who folded them so as to form the volume for the upper text . The text is most distinctly legible on the upper half of foll. 19 and 20, which served as fly-leaves to the manuscript in its later form.
The last of the leaves is much torn. Leaves are wanting after foll. 1 , 5 , 8 , 9 , and 16

Seven vellum leaves, about 7 1/4 in. by 5 3/8, the last of which is slightly torn. There are from 25 to 27 lines in each page. They contain part of the metrical discourse of Jacob of Batnae on the Divine Love, $‹°‹ê‹°‹™‹ê ‹ï‹•‹† ‹ö‹ò‹í‹ê ‹ê‹†‹ó‹ù‹ê, imperfect both at the beginning and end.

A manuscript, about 7 3/8 in. by 4 3/4, consisting of 146 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 80‚Äî82, 91‚Äî100, and 130‚Äî164. Foll. 63‚Äî80 are paper, the rest vellum. Vellum, about 10 5/8 in. by 8 1/2, consisting of 208 leaves, many of which are much stained, defaced and torn, especially foll. 1, 6, 7, 9, 10, 16, 17, 88, 89, 91, 93, 98, 100, 112, 118, 127, 132,185 and 198‚Äî208. Paper, about 10 1/8 in. by 6 7/8 consisting of 187 leaves, many of which are much soiled and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî5 and 141‚Äî187. Vellum, about 6 1/8 in. by 4 3/8, consisting of 307 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll.1, 55, 63‚Äî65, 71, 98, 99, 306 and 307. Paper, about 9 3/8 in. by 6 3/4 consisting of 82 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 30, 35‚Äî39,43‚Äî 47, and 74‚Äî82, whilst others have been repaired at a comparatively early period. Vellum, about 9 1/4 in. by 6 7/8, consisting of 13 leaves, most of which are much frayed or torn along the outer edges. Each page is divided into two columns, of from 25 to 29 lines. This manuscript is a palimpsest with the exception of fol. 9. The Syriac text has been washed off, to facilitate the reading of more ancient palimpsest texts, so that only fol. 9 now remains in its original condition. These leaves are remarkable for being doubly palimpsest.
This manuscript is a palimpsest with the exception of fol. 9. These leaves are remarkable for being doubly palimpsest, the writing of the less ancient of which is most legible on foll. 2, 7, and 10.

This manuscript is a palimpsest with the exception of fol. 9. These leaves are remarkable for being doubly palimpsest, the writing of the more ancient of which is is most plainly visible on foll. 1 b and 5 a. Each page is divided into two columns of 24 lines.

Vellum, about 7 1/4 in. by 5 1/8, consisting of 113 leaves. The quires, signed with letters, were 12 in number, but the first is now lost. Leaves are also wanting after foll. 75 and 103 . There are from 20 to 29 lines in each page.

Vellum, about 7 1/4 in. by 5 1/8, consisting of 40 leaves (Add. 17,168, foll. 114‚Äî153). The quires, four in number, are signed with letters from ‹ê to ‹ï , and afterwards from ‹ù‹ì to ‹ù‹ò . There are from 19 to 25 lines in each page.

The two leaves numbered 123 and 124 did not originally form part of this manuscript , but were added to it, as fly-leaves, when it was last bound in the convent. physicalDescription: Vellum, about 10 1/2 in. by 7 1/4, consisting of 85 leaves, some of which are much stained and slightly torn, especially foll. 11, 13, 20, 22, 29, 62, and 85. Vellum, about 7 1/4 in. by 5 1/4, consisting of 93 leaves, a few of which are slightly stained and soiled, especially foll. 1 , 9 , 10 , and 93 . Vellum, about 11 in. by 8 1/2, consisting of 110 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn, especially foll. 1‚Äî6, 10, 14, 24, 41, 45, 51, 61, 91, 94, and 97‚Äî109. Vellum, about 5 3/8 in. by 4, consisting of 151 leaves, a few of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 117, 120, 126, 145, and 151. The quires, signed with letters, were probably 18 in number, of which the first and last are missing. The number of lines in each page varies from 13 to 26. From fol. 117 onwards, this manuscript contains numerous palimpsest leaves, several of which belong to the rare class of double palimpsests. They appear to have been taken from no less than five manuscripts (see Add. 17,136, foll. 117 and 126, upper text 1 , Add. 17,136, foll. 117 and 126, lower text , Add. 17,136, foll. 120, 137, and 139, upper text 1 , Add. 17,136, foll. 120, 137, and 139, lower text , Add. 17,136, foll. 124-125, 128, 130-132, 135-136, 138, 140, 142-143, 147-148, and 150-151, lower text , Add. 17,136, foll. 118, 123, 133, 141, 145, and 149, lower text , and Add. 17,136, fol. 146, lower text ). Foll. 119, 121, 122, 127, 129, 134, and 144, do not present any traces of being palimpsest.

Vellum, about 9 5/8 in. by 6 1/2. Vellum, about 10 3/4 in. by 8 1/2, consisting of 126 leaves, some of which are much stained and slightly torn, especially foll. 1 , 61 , 62 , 120 , and 126 . Vellum, about 10 3/4 in. by 8 5/8. This volume is palimpsest throughout (see Add MS 14,623, upper text ), and the miserable monk Aaron deserves the execration of every theologian and Syriac scholar, for having destroyed a manuscript of the vith cent. , written in three columns, containing works of Ephraim, some of which are as yet unedited. Fortunately a portion of it (nineteen leaves) escaped his ruthless hands, and now forms a part of Add. 14,574 (see no. DXXXV .).

Paper, about 10 ¬º in. by 6 7/8, consisting of 201 leaves, some of which are slightly stained and torn. The quires, signed with letters, are 21 in number. A leaf is wanting at the beginning.
